summary: A Federal Bureau of Prisons legal hold notice sent on August 14, 2019, requiring preservation of all records and electronically stored information related to the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein, who was found unresponsive in his cell on August 10, 2019, and later pronounced dead. The notice instructs custodians not to destroy or alter any potentially relevant information.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell on August 10, 2019, at around 6:30 am, and was later pronounced dead at a local hospital.
The Federal Bureau of Prisons issued a legal hold notice on August 14, 2019, to preserve all records and electronically stored information related to Epstein's death, as litigation was anticipated.

The notice explicitly warns that knowingly altering, editing, or deleting potentially relevant information could result in court-ordered sanctions against the BOP and/or employment action against staff.
The legal hold applies to electronic files (emails, Word documents, TRUSCOPE entries, videos, BEHR records) and all handwritten or other physical documents pertaining to inmate Epstein.
Custodians were required to certify compliance with preservation obligations by clicking a confirmation link and returning a document search checklist by August 21, 2019.
